sentences: RuPaul Andre Charles (born November 17, 1960), known mononymously as RuPaul, is an American drag queen, television judge, recording artist, and model.

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: RuPaul was born in San Diego, California, on November 17, 1960, the son of Ernestine "Toni" (née Fontenette) and Irving Andrew Charles.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His parents were both from Louisiana.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He was named by his mother; "Ru" came from roux, the term for the base of gumbo and other creole stews and soups.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: According to Finding Your Roots, his DNA composition is 70% African and 30% European.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: When his parents divorced in 1967, he and his three sisters lived with their mother.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He was raised in the Catholic faith.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: At 15, RuPaul and his sister Renetta moved to study performing arts in Atlanta, Georgia.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In the ensuing years, RuPaul struggled as a musician and filmmaker during the 1980s, where he worked at Atlanta's famed Plaza Theatre.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 1982, he debuted on an Atlanta public access variety show called The American Music Show, on which he made frequent appearances over the years.:
section: == Early life ==

sentences: 59  He also participated in underground cinema, helping create the low-budget film Star Booty, and an album by the same name.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In Atlanta, RuPaul often performed at the Celebrity Club, managed by Larry Tee, as a bar dancer or with his band, Wee Wee Pole.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: RuPaul also performed as a backup singer to Glen Meadmore along with drag queen Vaginal Davis.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: RuPaul's first prominent national exposure came in 1989 dancing as an extra in the video for "Love Shack" by The B-52's.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In the early 1990s, RuPaul worked the Georgia club scene and was known by his full birth name.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Initially participating in gender bender-style performances, RuPaul performed solo and in collaboration with other bands at several New York City nightclubs, most notably the Pyramid Club.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He played opposite New York City drag performer Mona Foote (Nashom Benjamin) in the one-act science-fiction parody "My Pet Homo" written and directed by Jon Michael Johnson for Cooper Square Productions.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He appeared for many years at the annual Wigstock drag festival and appeared in the documentary Wigstock: The Movie.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In the 1990s, RuPaul was known in the UK for his appearances on the Channel 4 series Manhattan Cable, a weekly series produced by World of Wonder and presented by American Laurie Pike about New York's public-access television system.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: On January 27, 2017, RuPaul announced that a new album would be released the week after.
section: == Career == | === 2017–2018: Remember Me, American, return to VH1, and Essential, Vol. 2 ===

sentences: The album, named Remember Me: Essential, Vol. 1 was put up for pre-order on February 2 and eventually released the next day.
section: == Career == | === 2017–2018: Remember Me, American, return to VH1, and Essential, Vol. 2 ===

sentences: It is a collection of new songs and remakes of classic RuPaul hits that feature new artists.
section: == Career == | === 2017–2018: Remember Me, American, return to VH1, and Essential, Vol. 2 ===

sentences: Two singles have been released from the album so far: "Rock It (To The Moon)" which is a new song loosely based on the lyrics and the melody of "Hey Booty" which was released on the Starrbooty soundtrack in 2007, and an updated version of RuPaul's 1996 hit single "Snapshot" from the album Foxy Lady.
section: == Career == | === 2017–2018: Remember Me, American, return to VH1, and Essential, Vol. 2 ===

sentences: The album failed to chart on the Dance Albums Chart but managed to debut at number four on the Billboard Dance Albums Sales Chart in the United States.

sentences: It also charted at number eleven on the UK Dance Albums Chart, becoming RuPaul's highest charting album on that chart, after Realness managed to debut and peak at number 13.

sentences: On March 24, 2017, RuPaul released his eleventh studio album, American.

sentences: Later that same day, the ninth regular season of RuPaul's Drag Race debuted on basic cable channel VH1, home of RuPaul's talk show in the 1990s.

sentences: This marked a move from expanded cable channel Logo TV, which aired all previous seasons of the show.
section: == Career == | === 2017–2018: Remember Me, American, return to VH1, and Essential, Vol. 2 ===

sentences: The season 9 premiere featured singer Lady Gaga as its guest judge and proved a success, with ratings of nearly 1,000,000 viewers, making it the series' most viewed episode.

sentences: This figure was double LogoTV's season 8 premiere ratings from the year prior, and triple VH1's usual Friday night viewership in that programming timeslot.

sentences: When the ratings were released, World of Wonder Productions announced they were casting contestants for a tenth season.

== Other ventures == | === Activism ===

sentences: RuPaul has been an active supporter of voter registration, producing a public service announcement supporting National Voter Registration Day and urging everyone to register.
section: == Other ventures == | === Activism ===

sentences: As RuPaul said voter ID laws vary from state to state; the details of the voter ID required in each state are provided by HeadCount and VoteRiders.
section: == Other ventures == | === Activism ===

sentences: As one in five LGBTQ adults are not registered to vote, voter registration efforts have expanded recently with several of the stars from RuPaul's Drag Race acting as Ambassadors for the Drag Out the Vote.
section: == Other ventures == | === Activism ===
== Impact ==

sentences: Impact ==
section: == Impact ==

sentences: RuPaul is considered to be the most commercially successful drag queen in the United States.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: He has been credited with creating wider exposure for drag queens from LGBT culture into mainstream society, thanks to his early-career chart success, and later, the successive climb in viewership of RuPaul's Drag Race.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: His talk show The RuPaul Show was the first-ever national talk show to have a drag queen as a host.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: Along with his partner Michelle Visage, he welcomed an array of high-profile guests such as Cher, Lil Kim, and Diana Ross over the show's 100-episode span.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: As well as having a variety of comedy skits, the show was noted for discussing topics such as black empowerment, female empowerment, misogyny, and liberal politics that were otherwise unheard of in 1990s television at the time.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: In 1999, RuPaul was awarded the Vito Russo Award at the GLAAD Media Awards for work in promoting equality in the LGBT community.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: RuPaul has also been noted as having a large part in RuPaul's Drag Race's continuous television success.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: By pioneering queer representation on television, many believe RuPaul to have essentially revolutionised the portrayal of the LGBTQ+ community on screen.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: He first won an Emmy for his work on the show in 2016, and one year later the show garnered eight nominations, including Outstanding Reality-Competition Program for the first time in its 11-season run, and a second consecutive win for RuPaul in the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Host for a Reality or Reality-Competition Program.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: In 2017, he was included in the annual Time 100 list of the most influential people in the world.
section: == Impact ==

sentences: In 2019, Fortune noted RuPaul as “easily the world's most famous” drag queen.
section: == Impact ==
== Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: Relationship with transgender community =
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===
== Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: RuPaul has a complex relationship with the transgender community, in part due to differing philosophies: through drag he seeks to mock gender and identity stereotypes, while in his view the trans community takes identity seriously.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: RuPaul's Drag Race has featured a number of contestants who are trans women, some of whom made their identity public while competing on the show, including Sonique, Carmen Carrera, Jiggly Caliente, Monica Beverly Hillz, Kenya Michaels and Gia Gunn.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: In 2017, Peppermint became the first contestant to compete throughout her season as an openly trans woman and, in 2021, Gottmik was the first to compete as an openly trans man.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: Other non-conforming gender identities expressed by former contestants include non-binary (Jinkx Monsoon, Adore Delano, Aja, Valentina, Divina de Campo and Ginny Lemon), genderfluid (Courtney Act and Kelly Mantle) and genderqueer (Violet Chachki and Sasha Velour).
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: In 2014, trans activists and former contestants Carmen Carrera and Monica Beverly Hillz criticized the show's use of words such as tranny and shemale, including the main challenge announcement phrase up to season 6, "You've got she-mail", which they described as transphobic.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: That year's season also included a "Female or She-male" segment that required contestants to guess whether various photographs featured cisgender "biological women" or "psychological women" (drag queens), causing further criticism.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: RuPaul and the producers issued a statement promising "to help spread love, acceptance and understanding" and Logo TV removed the "You've got she-mail" phrase from subsequent broadcasts.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: RuPaul criticized those attempting to police his language in bad faith and noted that tranny referred to transvestites and drag queens, not just trans women.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: In 2018, RuPaul gave an interview to The Guardian in which he stated that a post-transition trans woman would "probably not" be accepted onto the show, noting that at the time of competition Peppermint had not yet had breast implants.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: After facing criticism on social media and from former contestants for his remarks, RuPaul compared trans drag queens who had transitioned to athletes who had taken performance-enhancing drugs.
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===

sentences: He subsequently expressed regret for the hurt caused by his remarks, and that the only screening criteria for contestants were "charisma, uniqueness, nerve, and talent".
section: == Impact == | === Relationship with transgender community ===
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: RuPaul met painter Georges LeBar in 1994 at the Limelight nightclub in New York City.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They married in January 2017.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They have an open marriage, with RuPaul stating he would not want to "put restraints" on the person he loves.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The two split their time between a home in Los Angeles and a 60,000-acre (24,000 ha) ranch in Wyoming.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The couple were criticized by environmentalists in 2020 after RuPaul revealed that they lease mineral rights and sell water to oil companies on their ranch, as well as allowing fracking, an environmentally harmful practice.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: There are at least 35 active wells on the ranch, according to public maps.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: RuPaul previously held a climate-themed ball on his show to raise environmental awareness, leading to accusations of hypocrisy.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: RuPaul publicly endorsed the Democratic Party nominee Hillary Clinton in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He expressed dismay at Clinton's defeat by Republican Party nominee Donald Trump, stating, "The America that we have all fought so hard for, the narrative of love and peace and liberty and equality, it feels like it is dead."
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He has described doing drag as a "very, very political" act because it "challenges the status quo" by rejecting fixed identities: "Drag says 'I'm a shapeshifter, I do whatever the hell I want at any given time'.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: "RuPaul has been sober from alcohol and drugs since 1999, having started smoking marijuana at age 10 or 11.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In 2020, he learned that he and New Jersey Senator Cory Booker are cousins; they discovered it by appearing on the TV show Finding Your Roots.
section: == Personal life ==
